Comment: Probably the most unsurprising thing in polling isn't that Trump's disapprovals are up but that his general approval among Republicans never really fluctuates. Trump consistently has high Republican approval no matter what happens, and this usually translates to a rock solid national approval between 36-42% depending on the poll you're looking at.  Likewise, Democrats don't seem to much change their minds on Trump.  The only people who change their minds on him keep flip flopping, and those are independents. I'm not really convinced of some of the article writers presentation, at least in the area of supporting some specific conclusions. Go to deep red country in Ohio and you'll get deep red country in Ohio opinions. These opinions are not defiant or counter to any polling about Trump; this is where that 36-42% of people who always approve of Trump no matter what live. I don't find highlighting their responses or feelings very revelatory. I could have farted out a random guess and been 100% correct about how they feel.  In that, the broader point the article notes is correct but it's been true since before the election. Hoping that opinion polls will salve reality is a false hope. Opinion polls have margins of error of a few percentage points. Guess how close the last couple elections have been? A few percentage points.  Polls aren't the issue. What lessons people try to take from polls is at issue and they've been an issue since 2020 when a lot of people seemed to overlook the dreary reality that Biden might have been the most voted for Presidential Candidate in US history, but Trump was the second most voted for. And these elections are not being made by partisans or dedicated politically active people. They're being decided by political outsiders and impromptu voters who are hard to account for in any polling and have frequently favored Trump over other candidates (including other Republicans going by 2024's results).
Author: Lord0fHats

Comment: If these people were merely voting due to their struggle then I think that ignoring them would be a bad way to go.  Except, that isn't what they're doing.  They vote for MAGA, at least in part, because they like that Trump hates the people that they hate.  They like that he speaks his mind about this hatred of people that they hate.  They'll even vote against their own interests in order to further this hate.  Farmers struggled under Trump the first go around and the US had to bail them out because of the tariffs that dried up their markets.  Yet, they lined back up to vote for him each time.  He claimed he'd save coal multiple times and yet coal hasn't been saved and has continued to falter.  Yet, the people of Appalachia came out in droves to support him.  When these people are asked why it isn't really ever about what he can do to economically save them, and if it is then it is at most that "he's bringing back American manufacturing," which none of them have ever felt the effects of, because he didn't do that either.  Instead, they speak of immigrants and trans people and how the left is crazy or communist or some other thing.  These people may be struggling but they aren't voting the way they are because they're actually victims of the economic times and seeking real help in that regard... they're voting the way they are because they're blaming other people for their problems and Trump is confirming that with his own message of hate.
